title: Democrats and Republicans unite — at least briefly, on a baseball diamond
content:
Sportsmanship is supposed to define the Congressional Baseball Game for Charity , bringing Democrats and Republicans together away from the Capitol . But last year , it was a tragedy surrounding the event that united the parties .
On June 14 , 2017 , no one knew whether Rep. Steve Scalise ( R-La . ) would live or die after a gunman opened fire on a GOP practice for the game . Scalise was shot in the left hip by an Illinois man who was reportedly upset that Donald Trump had been elected president . The lawmaker , one of five people wounded at the practice in Alexandria , Virginia , underwent multiple surgeries in the weeks that followed .
“ For all the noise and all the fury , we are one family , ” House Speaker Ryan said that afternoon .
Exactly one year later , Scalise was cheered as he came onto the field Thursday night for the annual game at Nationals Park . As he prepared to take second base — the same position he was playing when wounded last year — he was escorted by David Bailey and Crystal Griner , the U.S. Capitol Police officers who had taken down the gunman despite suffering injuries themselves .
It didn ’ t take long for Scalise to get warmed up , fielding a ball hit by Rep. Raul Ruiz ( D-Calif. ) in the first inning and getting a round of high-fives and applause as he exited the field .

The sense of unity between parties echoed the one felt last year , when the game was dedicated to Scalise while he was still in the hospital . The Democratic side ’ s manager , Rep. Mike Doyle of Pennsylvania , even gave his team ’ s winning trophy to Republicans to put in Scalise ’ s office .
But if this year is anything like last year , the sense of camaraderie might not last long .
After the 2017 game , Republicans pushed to loosen firearms laws — an unexpected move from lawmakers who had just experienced gun violence firsthand . The proposals included three bills that would allow lawmakers to carry concealed weapons most of the time , another that would allow concealed-carry permits obtained in other states to be recognized in the District of Columbia , and another that would eliminate federal controls on silencers .
“ It says everything about my colleagues that they would use the occasion of a tragedy on one of our members to come forward the day after with one of these bills , ” Del . Eleanor Holmes Norton ( D-D.C. ) said following the shooting .
Rep. Barry Loudermilk ( R-Ga. ) , who was on the practice field when the gunman opened fire , said in response to advocates of gun control : “ Have they ever been shot at , multiple times , at close range , trying to save someone without any way to defend yourself ? When you ’ ve experienced that yourself , maybe then we can have this debate . ”
In an interview with Fox News ’ Martha MacCallum late last year , Scalise said his experience “ fortified ” his views on the Second Amendment .
A year and several mass shootings later — including the killing of 14 students and three staff members at a Florida high school in February — Congress still hasn ’ t been able to come together to address gun regulations .
The survivors of the shooting in Parkland , Florida , pressed Republican lawmakers for change , challenged the National Rifle Association in public debates and spawned the March for Our Lives demonstration in March .
Following the Parkland shooting , President Donald Trump met with students and staff from Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School and suggested that teachers be armed to increase school safety .
Beyond the issue of gun violence , Republicans and Democrats remain divided over the administration and the president himself — from policy differences to the ongoing special counsel ’ s investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election .
In recent days , the issue of immigration and the Trump administration ’ s “ zero tolerance ” policy on families coming across the Mexican border has pitted the parties against each other in a nasty battle .
On Thursday , the coach for the GOP baseball team , Rep. Roger Williams ( R-Texas ) , told The Associated Press that he ’ d asked Trump to attend the game and that the president said , “ I ’ ll be there. ” Other presidents have made an appearance , including Barack Obama in 2015 , but Trump ended up not attending on Thursday , which was also his 72nd birthday .
The annual game , which raises money for various charities , brought in more than $ 1.5 million last year , with proceeds going to organizations like the Boys and Girls Club of Greater Washington , the Washington Nationals Dream Foundation and the Washington Literacy Center .
On Thursday night , the seven-inning contest ended 21-5 , with Democrats prevailing for the second year in a row . Both teams lined up to shake hands and exchange congratulations , then stuck around for photo-ops . Whether the cooperation and goodwill would last was a question for the following workday .
